Authors: Salim K.A., Hendarti R., Tomasowa R.
Title: Parametric facade approach for an office building to reduce the irradiance level in Jakarta
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, K.A., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hendarti, R., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Tomasowa, R., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Energy used in multi-storey office building is mostly for air conditioning, and it is acknowledged that the energy could be minimized by reducing the cooling load. In general, the cooling loads are from internal and external heat. The external heat plays significantly in determining the cooling load; therefore, it is necessary to reduce the amount of solar radiation received by the external surface of the building. The objective of the paper is to investigate the reduction of solar radiation received by the surface of the multi-storey office building by applying parametric design study and to add a building envelope as the secondary skin as well as the architectural element. There are two steps of analysis in the methodology, (1) to conduct solar radiation analysis, and (2) to conduct building facade analysis. In the process, four alternatives form were simulated to obtain the most optimum shape in relation to the incident solar radiation reduction. The final parametric study results of the solar radiation and building facade analysis showed that the reduction of the irradiance is around 25% with the additional facades. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: irradiance reduction; office building; parametric facade
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling; Facades; Office buildings; Architectural element; Building envelopes; Building facades; External surfaces; Irradiance level; Parametric design; Parametric study; Radiation analysis; Incident solar radiation

Authors: Suharjanto G., Salim K.A., Mariana Y., Wijaksono S.
Title: Perforated metal made from recycled material in the application of building facade
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suharjanto, G., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Salim, K.A., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Mariana, Y., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wijaksono, S., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Building material can be acquired effortlessly nowadays, but it still has limit and eventually the resources we have will run out. Building material decomposed in various time, some of it even take hundreds of years. This paper focus on the recycling metal waste material in form of perforated metal that used as building facade element. As we know that sustainable architecture not a simple design, and because of the lack of information until no interest in trying to execute the sustainable concept. Building material in metal form can be recycled and reused more easily thanks to the advanced technology invented. Perforated metal that can be designed in various ways and size can be used as building facade that enhance not only building performance but also the aesthetic aspect which emerged from the building. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: building facade; perforated metal; recycled material
Index Keywords: Building materials; Facades; Recycling; Advanced technology; Building facades; Building performance; Know-that; Recycled materials; Run outs; Sustainable architecture; Metals
References: Hegger, M., (2002) Construction Materials Manual; Munn, S., Soebarto, V., The issues of using recycled materials in architecture (2004) Issue Context of Architecture, pp. 161-167; Amponsah, N., Impact of building material recycle or reuse on selected emergy ratios (2012) Resources, Conservation and Recycling, 67, pp. 9-17; Rathmann, K., (1997) Recycling and Reuse of Builidng Materials; Schittich, C., (2006) Detail Building Skins; New life of the building materials-recycle, reuse and recovery (2015) Energy Procedia, 75, pp. 2884-2891. , W.
